instruction:
Your function: TCFD designate.

Text:
The Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) has identified climate-related risks as a potential threat to the financial stability of the United States. In response, the FSOC has mandated the Financial Stability Board (FSB) to develop a framework for enhancing climate-related disclosures by financial institutions and insurance companies. As the TCFD authority, your role will be to implement and promote the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) within your organization.

Text:
As the TCFD authority, your responsibilities include:

1. Understanding the TCFD recommendations and how they apply to your organization.
2. Developing a plan to implement the TCFD recommendations.
3. Engaging with senior management and the board of directors to secure their support for the implementation of the TCFD recommendations.
4. Collaborating with other departments and external stakeholders to ensure a coordinated approach to TCFD implementation.
5. Communicating the progress and outcomes of TCFD implementation to stakeholders, including investors, regulators, and the public.

Text:
To effectively carry out your role as the TCFD authority, it is essential that you have a solid understanding of the TCFD recommendations and how they apply to your organization. The TCFD framework consists of four key areas: governance, strategy, risk management, and metrics and targets. Each area includes specific recommendations that financial institutions and insurance companies should consider when disclosing climate-related risks and opportunities.

Text:
Governance refers to the role of the board of directors and senior management in overseeing climate-related risks and opportunities. The TCFD recommends that organizations establish a clear line of responsibility for climate-related risks and opportunities and ensure that the board of directors is informed about these risks and opportunities.

Text:
Strategy involves the development of a climate-related business strategy that takes into account the risks and opportunities associated with climate change. The TCFD recommends that organizations assess the potential impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on their business model, strategy, and financial planning.

Text:
Risk management involves the identification, assessment, and management of climate-related risks and opportunities. The TCFD recommends that organizations develop a process for identifying, assessing, and managing climate-related risks and opportunities, and disclose this process to stakeholders.

Text:
Metrics and targets refer to the measurement and reporting of climate-related risks and opportunities. The TCFD recommends that organizations establish metrics and targets to measure and report on their climate-related risks and opportunities, and disclose this information to stakeholders.

Text:
By implementing the TCFD recommendations, your organization will be able to provide more transparent and comprehensive information about its climate-related risks and opportunities to investors, regulators, and the public. This will help build trust and confidence in your organization's ability to manage climate-related risks and opportunities effectively.

Text:
In conclusion, as the TCFD authority, your role is critical in ensuring that your organization effectively manages climate-related risks and opportunities and discloses this information to stakeholders in a transparent and comprehensive manner. By implementing the TCFD recommendations, you will help build trust and confidence in your organization and contribute to a more stable and sustainable financial system.

input:

 Describe the organization’s processes for managing climaterelated risks

output:
Our company's Approach to Managing Risks:
Risk management in our organization encompasses all functions, including identifying risks related to financial and market performance, operational efficiency, emergency preparedness and response, environmental compliance, and regulatory impacts. We prioritize risks based on their potential impact on our business, employees, communities, and customers. Our Enterprise Risk Management program identifies, assesses, prioritizes, and manages key enterprise risks, with climate-related risks and opportunities being an integral part of this process.

Our Finance, Internal Audit, Legal, and Investor Relations departments evaluate domestic and international business risks, financial risks, market risks, and environmental compliance risks. These risks are evaluated as part of financial disclosure requirements. In addition, departments such as Environment, Health and Safety, Corporate Sales and Marketing, Legal, Operations, and Investor Relations assess specific physical and transitional risks and opportunities due to climate change. We have evaluated potential physical climate change risks to major facilities, including sea level rise flooding, susceptibility to and preparation for high intensity storms, increased rainfall, drought, and water stress and availability. Both company-level and asset-level physical and transitional risks have been considered, as well as raw material sourcing issues and distribution channel impacts. We use $1 million USD as a threshold for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.

Our company employs a materiality assessment to review and prioritize sustainability topics, including corporate governance, products, environmental protection (including climate change), social responsibility, and economic performance. Our top management is consulted to discuss which aspects are most relevant for our company's future success, and external stakeholders are consulted to understand their perspectives. The results from the materiality assessment guide us toward which areas to focus on in the future. Our Environment, Health & Safety department is responsible for maintaining our ISO 14001 certifications. Our ISO 14001 environmental management systems involve assessing environmental impacts of our manufacturing operations, including those impacted by climate change. Significant impacts for each site covered under an ISO 14001 certification are determined using a ranking system.

We have established corporate-wide goals to manage climate-related risks. Our sustainability goals include a climate change-related target of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions by 50% by 2030 relative to a base year of 2019. We also have a long-term goal of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions in line with the Paris Agreement to further reduce our climate impact and support limiting warming to 1.5°C and transitioning to a net-zero carbon economy.

Upstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on the suppliers of our raw materials. As we rely on global suppliers for raw materials, their locations may be subject to various supply constraints, including those due to climate change. In situations where our company depends on a limited number of suppliers for certain raw materials, components, services, and equipment used in the manufacturing of our products, climate change-related risks could affect us. For instance, chronic drought or flooding could increase instability in regions of the world that supply critical raw materials, causing business interruptions. We use $1 million USD as a threshold for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.

Our company assesses upstream risks by calculating our upstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Procurement department manages both physical and transitional risks and opportunities in our supply chain. Our dedicated staff, Supplier Code of Conduct, Purchase Order Terms and Conditions, and Responsible Minerals Sourcing Policy help us manage potential supply chain risks, including those associated with climate change. Where feasible, we seek to obtain goods and services from local suppliers in the locations where we conduct business, which helps reduce our risk of business interruptions when climate-related issues may arise and lowers transportation emission impacts.

Downstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on our business downstream. We believe climate change presents a potential opportunity for us because our products are specifically designed to reduce energy consumption and GHG emissions compared to incumbent technologies. However, climate-related events could cause delays in product distribution, resulting in commercial risks associated with delivering our products in a timely manner. We use $1 million USD as a threshold for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.

Our company assesses downstream risks by calculating our downstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Corporate Sales and Marketing department manages our climate-related transitional risks and opportunities, including those related to our product sales, our reputation, market projections, and consumer preferences. We assess market trends and technology advancements to suggest what our business focus should be. For example, we have shifted our strategic focus toward our semiconductor business due to the anticipated increased adoption of energy-efficient technologies that use our products (e.g., renewable energy, electric vehicles).

instruction: Your proficiency in the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework is crucial for performing comprehensive assessments of organizational strategies and risk management procedures. input:
1. Describe the organization’s processes for identifying and assessing climate- related risks 
 Describe the organization’s processes for managing climaterelated risks 
 Describe how processes for identifying, assessing, and managing climaterelated risks are integrated into the organization’s overall risk management.
output:
Our company's Direct Operations:
Risk management in our organization involves all functions, including assessing risks related to financial and market performance, operational performance, emergency preparedness and response, environment, health and safety compliance, and regulatory impacts. We prioritize risks based on their impact on our business, employees, communities, and customers. Our Enterprise Risk Management program identifies, assesses, prioritizes, and manages key enterprise risks, with climate-related risks and opportunities being part of this process.
Our Finance, Internal Audit, Legal, and Investor Relations departments identify and assess business risks, financial risks, market risks, and environmental compliance risks for our organization. These risks are reviewed as part of financial disclosure requirements. In addition, departments such as Environment, Health and Safety, Corporate Sales and Marketing, Legal, Operations, and Investor Relations assess specific physical and transitional risks and opportunities due to climate change. We have evaluated potential physical climate change risks to major facilities, including sea level rise flooding, susceptibility to and preparation for high intensity storms, increased rainfall, drought, and water stress and availability. Both company-level and asset-level physical and transitional risks have been considered, as well as raw material sourcing issues and distribution channel impacts. We use $1 million USD as a threshold for substantive financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company uses a materiality assessment to review and prioritize sustainability topics, including corporate governance, products, environmental protection (including climate change), social responsibility, and economic performance. Our top management is interviewed to discuss which aspects are most relevant for our company's future success, and external stakeholders are consulted to understand their perspectives. The results from the materiality assessment guide us toward which areas to focus on in the future. Our Environment, Health & Safety department is responsible for maintaining our ISO 14001 certifications. Our ISO 14001 environmental management systems involve assessing environmental impacts of our manufacturing operations, including those impacted by climate change. Significant impacts for each site covered under an ISO 14001 certification are determined using a ranking system.
We have established corporate-wide goals to manage climate-related risks. Our sustainability goals include a climate change-related target of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions by 50% by 2030 relative to a base year of 2019. We also have a long-term goal of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions in line with the Paris Agreement to further reduce our climate impact and support limiting warming to 1.5°C and transitioning to a net-zero carbon economy.
Upstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on the suppliers of our raw materials. As we rely on global suppliers for raw materials, their locations may be subject to various supply constraints, including those due to climate change. In instances where our company depends on a limited number of suppliers for certain raw materials, components, services, and equipment used in the manufacturing of our products, climate change-related risks could affect us. For example, chronic drought or flooding could increase instability in regions of the world that supply critical raw materials, causing business interruption. We use $1 million USD as a threshold for substantive financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company assesses upstream risks by calculating our upstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Procurement department manages both physical and transitional risks and opportunities in our supply chain. Our dedicated staff, Supplier Code of Conduct, Purchase Order Terms and Conditions, and Responsible Sourcing Policy help us manage potential supply chain risks, including those associated with climate change. Where possible, we seek to obtain goods and services from local suppliers in the locations where we conduct business, which helps reduce our risk of business interruptions when climate-related issues may arise and lowers transportation emission impacts.
Downstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on our business downstream. We believe climate change presents a potential opportunity for us because our products are specifically designed to reduce energy consumption and GHG emissions compared to incumbent technologies. However, climate-related events could cause delays in product distribution, resulting in commercial risks associated with delivering our products in a timely manner. We use $1 million USD as a threshold for substantive financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company assesses downstream risks by calculating our downstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Sales and Marketing department manages our climate-related transitional risks and opportunities, including those related to our product sales, our reputation, market projections, and consumer preferences. We assess market trends and technology advancements to suggest what our business focus should be. For example, we have shifted our strategic focus toward energy-efficient technologies that use our products (e.g., renewable energy, electric vehicles).

instruction: Prepared to offer guidance on risk management, drawing from your proficiency with the TCFD framework.
input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Managing climate-related risk and opportunities
output:
Our company does not see any substantial transitional or physical risks from climate change that have a material impact on us, but rather view the transition toward a low carbon economy as an opportunity. Climate change and its mitigation are significant issues for our stakeholders. We enable our customers to lower their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by providing low carbon and energy-efficient products, solutions, and services. Our Environmental Portfolio (EP) helps our customers to mitigate their CO2 footprint, reduce energy costs, and improve profitability through higher productivity. In fiscal 2020, we managed to reduce 150 million metric tons of CO2 at customer sites. Our business SI, for example, has been established with a priority focus on decentralization, decarbonization, and energy efficiency in buildings and cities. SI strategy addresses the ongoing challenges and seizes the opportunities of new technologies around the grid edge with products and solutions for decentralized energy systems, photovoltaic inverters, energy storage, smart and sustainable buildings, and electro mobility, enabled by digitalization. For instance, we have been guaranteeing energy performance contracts since 1995 and have to date enabled our customers to save 13 million tons of CO2.

With respect to our own operations, we are committed to becoming carbon neutral by 2030. This year, we managed to halve our emissions compared to 2014. Among other benefits, this program reduces potential carbon taxational risk on our operations. Through our dedicated decarbonization program within the supply chain, we also reduce this risk upstream.

Regarding potential physical risks, we continuously evaluate and monitor changes in climate parameters based on global studies, weather statistics, and trends based on international experience of insurance companies. We do not consider those risks to lead to substantive changes in operations, revenue, or expense as they allow for mitigation. In addition, we perform local risk assessments and develop protection concepts if needed. Furthermore, our insurance department provides natural hazard risks analysis for each new building project that drives the selection process for new site areas and influences technical, organizational, and physical protection measures. The collected data and information allow us to identify geographical areas where we pay special attention at our sites in terms of risks from changes to physical climate parameters. For example, at one of our sites, we installed flood protection measures in 2013 as a preventative measure. This measure was put to the test in 2018 and proved effective, as our site was not impacted despite heavy floods within the area. In 2020, we further enhanced our processes for physical risk assessment due to a more competitive insurance market with less overall insurer capacity, most likely driven by increasing overall impacts of natural disasters.

Jointly with our insurer and our risk management partner, we evaluate 80% of our insured value with respect to fire safety but also natural catastrophes, such as storms, floods, hurricanes, on a yearly basis. The analysis was based on RMS (Risk Management Solution) data. This analysis revealed that major sites were exposed. We see floods exposure mainly in Europe, whereas some sites in the U.S., Philippines, or Japan are exposed to storms or hurricanes. For these identified sites, a more detailed risk analysis was performed, and results were provided to our insurer to adjust payment conditions. In addition, and in alignment with our overall EHS emergency response management system, we provided measures to be taken by the identified sites, such as installation of flood barriers, thickening of roofs. The requirements for risk mitigation measures are continuously enhanced and consider risk changes.

This process is complementary to the implementation of our company's Water Strategy. Based on our global binding EHS regulation, every environmentally relevant site must perform a risk assessment. This includes the evaluation of water-related climate change risks, such as their water stress level, exposure to flooding, droughts, and general water availability. For this assessment, we use Aqueduct (WRI) and IPCC data to predict changes in precipitation. This assessment is verified by our internal tool with each site responsible for performing a bottom-up analysis. In fiscal 2020, we had analyzed 97% of locations.

One example for an acute physical risk could be from drought in water-stressed areas. One of our sites in India has established a comprehensive water management system with active collection of rainwater during the monsoon, which is fed back into the ground to increase necessary groundwater level during the dry season instead of letting it run off through sewers. In addition, the site benefits, as it is more independent from the public water supply.

Natural disasters could potentially interrupt our supply chain. However, supply chain risks are low due to our diversified supplier base, worldwide operations, and a limited number of our company's facilities concentrated in any particular region, including those regions more likely to be affected by natural disasters. Nevertheless, we analyze potential supply chain disruptions both within our supplier selection and qualification process as well as in the phase of continuous supply chain operations. Based on external real-time data from service provider risk methods, which indicates risk alerts in any region worldwide, our businesses are mitigating upcoming supply chain risks to ensure flawless deliveries to our customers. Due to proven risk indicators such as natural disasters, COVID-19-related lockdown areas, and financial alert data, which will be supported through AI-driven data analytics, we preventively managed several risk cases (e.g., COVID-19, natural disasters) to ensure the resilience of our supply chain during major crises.

input: 1. Climate-related scenario analysis
output:
Our company considers ourselves a leading partner in the decarbonization process for our customers and society. We are committed to providing innovative technologies to facilitate this transformation of the energy value chain over the next few decades. To achieve this, we have developed comprehensive multi-modal simulation tools and compared the results with external research studies, such as International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), Fraunhofer, IHS, Agora Energiewende, and International Energy Agency (IEA).

Regarding our own operations, we conducted scenario analysis as a stress test on our carbon neutral program to ensure its resilience to higher energy or CO2-prices. Our experts applied high-price scenarios using various sources, including industry reports and think tanks, to identify potential risks to our CO2-reduction plan. By utilizing predictions on energy prices and a forecast for CO2 prices from reputable sources, we evaluated necessary adjustments. The results of the analysis showed that our existing program is sufficiently resilient.

Climate-related scenario analysis enables our business to anticipate potential consequences from regulatory changes, R&D, and customer trends and requirements. In fiscal 2020, we performed forward-looking scenario analysis in accordance with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendation. Besides industry reports, we applied the Sustainable Development Scenario (SDS) from the International Energy Agency (IEA), examining indicators such as renewable uptake, decentralization, energy efficiency demand, and CO2 prices for 2020-2040. The project did not influence our strategy but strongly confirmed it. The analysis revealed that our portfolio is resilient to climate change. In fact, the majority of our portfolio benefits from energy transformation, including Virtual Power Plants (VPP), Decentralized Energy Systems (DES), future grids, Digital Grids (DG), and storage, and will even be stronger in the next decades.

instruction: Prepare in-depth reports for financial institutions, utilizing your extensive knowledge of the TCFD framework. These reports should outline the steps for integrating climate-related risks into risk management structures, with a strong emphasis on the importance of specific metrics and targets.
input: 1. Enterprise risk management process
output:
Our company has established and overseen a set of risk management and control systems to support the early recognition of potential threats to our business continuity. These systems consist of enterprise-wide processes for strategic planning and management reporting. Strategic planning enables us to identify potential risks prior to significant business decisions, while management reporting allows us to closely monitor risks as our business progresses. Our internal auditors regularly evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of our risk management, and any deficiencies can be addressed through appropriate measures.

Our risk management approach is comprehensive, interactive, and management-focused, and is integrated into our organization. It addresses both risks and opportunities. Our approach is based on globally recognized standards, such as the COSO Framework and ISO 31000, and is customized to meet our company's specific needs. The frameworks connect our risk management process with our financial reporting process and internal control system.

Our risk management process aims for early identification and evaluation of risks and opportunities that could materially impact our strategic, operational, financial, and compliance objectives. The time horizon is typically three years, and we take a net risk approach, addressing risks and opportunities that remain after the implementation of existing control measures. Relevant risks and opportunities are identified in a structured manner, combining elements of both top-down and bottom-up approaches. Reporting generally follows a quarterly cycle, with an ad-hoc reporting process to escalate critical issues in a timely manner.

Relevant risks and opportunities are prioritized based on impact and likelihood, considering various perspectives, including business objectives, reputation, and regulatory requirements. The bottom-up identification and prioritization process is supplemented by workshops with the respective management of our organizational units. The top-down element ensures that potential new risks and opportunities are discussed at different management levels and are included in the subsequent reporting process, if deemed relevant.

Reported risks and opportunities are analyzed for potential cumulative effects and are aggregated within and for each of the business units. Responsibilities are assigned for all relevant risks and opportunities, with the level of responsibility depending on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. Our response strategies include avoidance, transfer, reduction, acceptance, and seizing opportunities. For each risk or opportunity, responsibility involves the development, initiation, and monitoring of appropriate response measures corresponding to the chosen response strategy. These response measures are specifically tailored to enable effective risk management.

Our company manages various risks, including those related to economic activity and customer demand, project risks, and risks from the transmission of infectious agents. We closely monitor macroeconomic conditions and developments in relevant industries to address the risk of fluctuation in economic activity and customer demand. We maintain appropriate insurance coverage for potential damage and liability risks to reduce our exposure and avoid or minimize potential losses. Our internal auditors regularly assess the adequacy and effectiveness of our risk management, and any deficiencies are addressed through appropriate measures. This coordination of processes and procedures aims to keep the Managing Board and the Supervisory Board informed about significant risks in a timely manner.

Our risk management approach is comprehensive, interactive, and management-oriented, integrated into the organization, and covers both risks and opportunities. It is based on globally accepted standards, such as the COSO Standard and ISO Standard 31000, and is adapted to our specific needs. The frameworks connect the risk management process with our financial reporting process and internal control system. They consider our strategy, the efficiency and effectiveness of our business operations, the reliability of our financial reporting, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations to be equally important.

Our risk management process aims for early identification and evaluation of risks and opportunities that could materially impact our strategic, operational, financial, and compliance objectives. These response measures must be specifically tailored to allow for effective risk management.

We address the risk of fluctuation in economic activity and customer demand by closely monitoring macroeconomic conditions and developments in relevant industries and adjusting capacity and implementing cost-reduction measures in a timely and consistent manner if necessary.

There are worldwide risks from the transmission of infectious agents from animals to humans, from humans to humans, and in other ways. instruction: In your role as a TCFD expert, you will be detailing the optimal approaches for conducting climate risk evaluations.
input: 1. Describe the Board's oversight of climate related risks and opportunities.
output:
Our company's Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) initiatives are overseen by the Board, which determines strategy and priority areas. The Board recognizes the importance of senior executive involvement and holistic oversight of ESG matters material to our organization. In 2020, a Group ESG Committee was established to provide this involvement. The Committee is chaired by the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer, and includes the Chief Risk and Compliance Officer, the HR Director, and senior representatives from our business units. One of the Group ESG Committee's responsibilities is to oversee our progress towards fulfilling our commitment to report against the recommendations of the Financial Stability Board’s Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD). In 2020, the Group ESG Committee reported to the Board through the Nomination & Governance Committee.

The Board acknowledges that the next 12 to 18 months are critical for the implementation of our ESG Strategic Framework and related matters, such as the development and embedding of our purpose and values, diversity and inclusion (D&I) priorities, and employee engagement activities. In early 2021, a Responsibility & Sustainability Working Group was established to ensure appropriate Board engagement and oversight during this period.

Our policies and procedures for managing ESG issues are outlined in our Group Governance Manual (GGM). The GGM is subject to an annual formal content review, taking into consideration internal and external factors. Any instances of GGM non-compliance identified through annual attestations are assessed by policy owners and reported to the Group Audit Committee.

Our company believes that our new strategic ESG framework and long-term goals to decarbonize our investment portfolio and support an inclusive transition are essential for meeting stakeholder expectations and fulfilling our fiduciary obligations. This approach will reduce our exposure to asset risk, including transition risk, over time, while also contributing to global decarbonization efforts. Our Risk function conducted an initial transition risk analysis on insurance assets managed in segregated portfolios by our asset managers. This analysis focused on investments where we maintain direct control and exert influence over the investment process. Provisional reports were produced using climate-related data and metrics provided through a proprietary vendor tool. This facilitates a breakdown of the contributions of different sectors to our overall carbon footprint metrics and highlights the most carbon-intensive sectors, including those most at risk of being stranded. It also enables the identification and monitoring of the most carbon-intensive companies held in our asset book. We have also determined the initial weighted average carbon intensity (WACI) of our listed equity and corporate bond asset classes.

The Board's oversight of climate change risk has been significantly strengthened. In 2020, ESG was overseen by the Board through the Nomination & Governance Committee. In early 2021, a Responsibility & Sustainability Working Group was established until May 2022 to ensure appropriate Board engagement and oversight of ESG matters (including climate change). A Board Risk Committee workshop was held to evaluate the climate change risks facing our organization, discuss transition and physical risk concepts, and review potential Key Risk Indicators (KRIs).

input: 1. Describe the impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on the organisation's businesses, strategy, and financial planning.
output:
After conducting a thorough ESG review, our company has established a new Strategic Framework (the 'framework'). This framework aligns with our business strategy and our mission to help individuals maximize their potential, build wealth, and achieve their savings goals. The framework consists of three strategic pillars, each with a clear connection to our business strategy. In each pillar, we have identified focus areas where our company can make a significant impact.

We are confident that our new ESG strategic framework and our long-term goals to decrease carbon emissions and promote an inclusive transition are essential for our company to meet stakeholder expectations and discharge our fiduciary duties. This framework will enable us to manage risk over the long term while contributing to global efforts to decarbonize the economy. Given that transition risk represents the most immediate and impactful financial risk, we have initiated an analysis of the carbon footprint of our investment portfolio. This analysis focused on investments where our company holds significant influence over the investment process. Preliminary reports were generated using climate-related data and metrics provided through a vendor tool. This process allows us to identify the carbon contributions of various sectors and determine the most carbon-intensive companies in our investment portfolio. We have also calculated the initial weighted average carbon intensity (WACI) for the listed equity and corporate bond asset classes in our investment portfolio.

Our company operates in markets with varying levels of development. Some markets boast diversified, service-led economies and mature financial markets, while others rely more on primary and energy-intensive industries. Emerging markets have a greater dependence on fossil fuels for their energy generation and less developed financial systems. The energy transition in these regions is expected to progress at a slower pace than in advanced economies. This was emphasized by Mr. Ravi Menon, Managing Director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), during a Financial Times Investing for Good Asia Digital Conference on October 13, 2020. Mr. Menon stated that 'Asia is at a different stage of development, with millions of people still lacking access to electricity, modern sanitation, and drinking water. While demand for affordable energy will continue to grow strongly, most Asian economies are still heavily dependent on fossil fuels for their energy needs, and it is unrealistic to suddenly replace fossil fuels with renewable energy.'

For our company, this implies that while we are committed to reducing carbon emissions in our investment portfolio, we recognize the importance of implementing this strategy in a manner that acknowledges the unique characteristics of the markets in which we operate and seeks to share the financial and social burden of the transition equitably. Our commitment to an inclusive transition aims to balance our responsibilities and obligations to all our stakeholders. We understand the significance of coalition building in driving an inclusive transition. As a member of the Sustainable Development Investment Partnership (SDIP), coordinated by the World Economic Forum with support from the OECD, we collaborate with public and private sector institutions in emerging markets, particularly in South-east Asia, to scale up domestic and international investment in sustainable infrastructure and promote energy transition. The SDIP’s ASEAN Hub, whose Steering Group our company has co-chaired since 2017, launched a Sustainable Investment Innovation Roundtable in 2020, a monthly forum to generate new ideas for scaling up investments to further the SDGs.

output:
After conducting a thorough ESG review, our company has established a new ESG Strategic Framework (the 'framework'). This framework aligns with our business strategy and our mission to help individuals maximize their potential, build wealth, and achieve their savings goals. The framework consists of three strategic pillars, each with a clear connection to our business strategy. In each pillar, we have identified specific focus areas where our company can make a significant impact.

We are confident that our new ESG framework and our long-term goals to decarbonize our investment portfolio and support a fair transition are essential for meeting stakeholder expectations and fulfilling our fiduciary duties. This approach will help us minimize asset risk, including transition risk, over time, while also contributing to global decarbonization efforts. Acknowledging that transition risk represents the most immediate and impactful financial risk, we have conducted an initial transition risk analysis on our investment assets. This analysis focused on investments where our company holds significant influence over the investment process. Preliminary reports were generated using climate-related data and metrics from a proprietary vendor tool. This analysis allows us to identify the carbon footprint contributions of various sectors in our investment portfolio and pinpoint the most carbon-intensive sectors, which are at the highest risk of being stranded. It also enables us to determine and monitor the most carbon-intensive companies in our investment portfolio. We have also calculated the initial weighted average carbon intensity (WACI) for our listed equity and corporate bond asset classes.

Our company operates in diverse markets, including mature economies with service-led industries and advanced financial markets, as well as emerging markets that are more reliant on primary and energy-intensive industries. These emerging markets have a greater dependence on fossil fuels for their energy generation and less developed financial systems. The energy transition in these regions is expected to progress at a slower pace than in advanced economies. This was emphasized by Mr. Ravi Menon, Managing Director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), during a Financial Times Investing for Good Asia Digital Conference on October 13, 2020. Mr. Menon stated that 'Asia is at a different stage of development, with millions of people still lacking access to electricity, modern sanitation, and drinking water. While demand for affordable energy will continue to grow strongly, most Asian economies are still heavily dependent on fossil fuels for their energy needs, and it is unrealistic to suddenly replace fossil fuels with renewable energy.'

For our company, this means that while we are committed to decarbonizing our investment portfolio, we recognize the importance of implementing this strategy in a manner that acknowledges the unique challenges of the markets in which we operate and seeks to share the financial and social burden of the transition equitably. Our commitment to a fair transition aims to balance our responsibilities and obligations to all our stakeholders. We understand the importance of collaboration in driving a fair transition. As a member of the Sustainable Development Investment Partnership (SDIP), coordinated by the World Economic Forum with support from the OECD, we collaborate with public and private sector institutions in emerging markets, particularly in South-east Asia, to scale domestic and international investment in sustainable infrastructure and promote energy transition. The SDIP’s ASEAN Hub, whose Steering Group our company has co-chaired since 2017, launched a Sustainable Investment Innovation Roundtable in 2020, a monthly forum to catalyze new ideas for scaling up investments to further the SDGs.

instruction: As a TCFD expert, I am here to help organizations enhance their climate reporting strategies for optimal performance.
input: 1. Describe the potential impact of different scenarios, including a 2°C scenario, on the organisation's businesses, strategy, and financial planning.
output:
Over the next three years, our company will work to enhance the management of climate risk across our organization. This will be a company-wide initiative with involvement from our asset owner and asset manager business units, risk, actuarial, and government relations teams.

Scenario analysis will be a key focus area as we plan to incorporate it into our mainstream risk management processes during 2021 and report findings within management information at the company and business unit levels. As we explore how climate risk impacts our business in the long term, we aim to operationalize and increase the use of scenario testing. We plan to voluntarily run scenario tests emerging from regulators, such as exploratory climate risk scenarios for financial institutions in 2021.

Many organizations have set targets in alignment with global climate goals. Our company is assessing similar targets in respect of the carbon emissions from our investments, given their significance within our overall emissions profile, and our commitment to decarbonizing our investment portfolio.

In the interim, we continue to increase our level of ambition in relation to our own emissions footprint. This year we have set new and stretching targets for our Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions, with the aim of becoming net carbon neutral across these two scopes by the end of 2030. More information on the environmental impact of our direct operations is available in the Environmental section on page 46.

During 2021, we will continue to scale up our engagement strategy with key policy and political stakeholders around major climate conferences, with a focus on financial sector issues to support the just transition and sustainable finance priorities, particularly in emerging markets. We also recognize that the implementation of our strategic ESG framework can generate opportunities for our company. Some of these opportunities will come through our efforts to take early mitigating action against the climate risks we identify, including incorporating transition risk into investment decisions to reduce the risk of being exposed to stranded assets. Others will come through supporting an inclusive transition. The infrastructure and capital expenditure required to enable the transition represents attractive investment opportunities in many cases. For example, there is a role for institutions to both develop new products and invest in structures and mechanisms that enable a managed withdrawal from reliance on coal-powered electricity within developing economies. In response to this, we have developed several responsible investment products that channel our customers’ savings towards ESG-themed investments, such as the Asia Sustainable Bond Fund recently launched by Eastspring. More information on our ESG-related investment activity is available in the Responsible Investment section on page 34.

A review is underway to assess suitable targets in respect of the carbon emissions from our investment portfolio. We are also exploring further environmental/climate risk opportunities, such as the development of investment, insurance and digital products to support climate risk management.

instruction: As your new role, you have been assigned the title of TCFD Strategist.
input:

1. Describe the climate-related risks and opportunities the organization has identified over the short, medium, and long term.
output:
Processes used to determine material risks and opportunities: Our company has developed capabilities to execute climate stress testing and scenario analysis to enhance our understanding of risk exposures for risk management and business decision making. Due to challenges in data sourcing and processes, there have been impacts on certain climate disclosures.

Climate scenario analysis is used as a risk assessment tool to provide insights on the long-term effects of transition and physical risks across our corporate and retail banking portfolios, as well as our own operations. Our sustainable finance initiative enables sustainable infrastructure and energy systems, promotes decarbonisation efforts across the real economy, and enhances investor capital through sustainable investment.

We aim to achieve net zero in our financed emissions by 2050 and in our own operations and supply chain by 2030. We aim to provide and facilitate $750bn to $1tn of sustainable finance and investment for our customers in their transition to net zero and a sustainable future.

Our assessment of climate risks covers three distinct time periods: short term (up to 2025), medium term (2026 to 2035), and long term (2036 to 2050). Transition or physical climate-related issues identified are assessed using enhanced questionnaires and scoring tools.

We support our customers in their transition through our sustainable finance and investment initiative. Our sustainable finance data dictionary includes a detailed definition of contributing activities.

Certain perils, such as coastal, river, and surface water flooding, drive potential credit losses in our retail portfolio. Around 20% of our financed properties are in a major city, and most are protected by a flood barrier.

We identified six key sectors with the highest exposure to climate transition risk: automotive, chemicals, construction and building materials, metals and mining, oil and gas, and power and utilities. We continued to improve our identification and assessment of climate risk within our retail mortgage portfolio, with increased investments in physical risk data and enhancements to our internal risk assessment capabilities and models.

Opportunities include sustainable finance, sustainable investment, and sustainable infrastructure. For a detailed breakdown of our sustainable finance progress by geography, see the ESG Data Pack.

We report our exposure to high transition risk sectors in our wholesale portfolio. Since 2020, we have rolled out the questionnaire to include our largest customers in the next highest climate transition risk sectors: agriculture, industrials, real estate, and transportation.

As a result of climate scenario analysis, our largest and most impacted sectors – power and utilities, construction and building materials, and chemicals – are subject to increased levels of transition risks. Our asset management division is increasingly considering both physical and transition risks and integrating ESG and climate analysis into the investment decision-making process.

Transition to net zero represents one of our strategic pillars. We aim to be net zero in our operations and supply chain by 2030 and in our financed emissions by 2050. Scenario analysis supports our strategy by assessing our position under a range of climate scenarios and helping us plan for the future and meet growing regulatory requirements.

We continue to develop our climate scenario analysis exercises to have a more comprehensive understanding of climate headwinds, risks, and opportunities that will support our strategic planning and actions. We do not currently fully disclose the impacts of climate-related issues on financial planning, particularly the impact on financial performance and financial position. We expect to further enhance our disclosure and processes in relation to acquisitions/divestments in the medium term.

Climate change poses a physical risk to the buildings we occupy as an organization, including offices, retail branches, and data centers. We use stress testing to evaluate the potential impact to our owned or leased premises. Our scenario stress test, conducted in 2022, analyzed how seven different climate change-related hazards could impact 500 of our critical and important buildings.

Our Climate Solutions Partnership is a philanthropic initiative that aims to identify and remove barriers to scale for climate change solutions. We support start-up companies developing carbon-cutting technologies, nature-based solutions, renewable energy initiatives, and the WWF-led Asia Sustainable Palm Oil Links programme.

During Board meetings, we balance discussions on the company's performance, emerging risks, and duties to shareholders while remaining conscious of responsibilities to support communities and help customers. In 2022, the Board approved an update to the thermal coal phase-out policy and the publication of an updated energy policy. We have committed to publishing our own climate transition plan in 2023.

Text:
Our company has identified the following climate-related risks and opportunities and their impact on our business activities. We have reinforced our commitment to promoting sustainable business practices within our organization to support the transition to a low-carbon society. We actively provide financial products and services that help mitigate climate change or facilitate adaptation to it, while implementing appropriate risk management based on international concerns, trends, and other factors.
Opportunities:
- Expanded business opportunities to offer financing for renewable energy projects or solutions for clients' transition to a low-carbon society.
- Enhanced reputation in capital markets and society at large through suitable initiatives and disclosures.
Risks:
- We consider both physical risks and transition risks.
- Our transition risks include financial risk from clients whose businesses may be negatively impacted by stricter carbon taxes, fuel efficiency regulations, or other policies, as well as delays in adopting low-carbon and other environmental technologies. Our transition risks also encompass reputational risk from financing projects that are not aligned with a low-carbon society.
- Our physical risks include operational risk from potential damage to our assets (such as data centers) due to extreme weather conditions and credit risk from customer assets (such as real estate collateral) that may be affected by climate-related events.

1. Describe the resilience of the organization’s strategy, taking into consideration different climate-related scenarios, including a 2°C or lower scenario.
output:
Scenario analysis - According to the TCFD Recommendations, our company's credit exposure (EXP) to carbon-related sectors represents 7.3% of our total credit exposure. Our transition risk assessment concentrates on the sectors of electric utilities and oil, gas & coal in Japan. The analysis timeframe spans until 2050, although the International Energy Agency (IEA) scenario only extends to 2040. The estimated cost increases under dynamic and static scenarios are approximately ¥120 billion and ¥310 billion, respectively. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) scenarios we considered are 8.5 (4°C) and 2.6 (2°C).

In evaluating potential impacts on our clients' businesses, we applied two scenarios: a static scenario, which assumes no change in the existing business structure, and a dynamic scenario, under which the business structure adapts to the transformation. Our analysis primarily focused on credit costs through 2050.

We utilized a Monte Carlo simulation to estimate the rates at which typhoons and other storms result in wind and water-related building loss or damage. We then analyzed the potential direct (collateral value) and indirect (business stagnation) impacts on our company's credit costs from the loss or damage of mortgaged real estate (buildings) in Japan. This analysis targeted middle-market firms and SMEs in Japan. The impact on mortgage lending value was minimal, while the impact of business stagnation was ¥52 billion at most under both 2°C and 4°C scenarios.

input: 1. Describe the climate-related risks and opportunities the organization has identified over the short, medium, and long term.
output:
In accordance with the TCFD framework, members of our ESG Committee identify and assess climate-related risks and response measures on a regular basis for our company. Every two years, we examine potential crises and opportunities related to climate change. In 2022, we identified one new transition risk (regulations regarding renewable energy and procurement) and one new opportunity (enhancing company reputation). We also eliminated one physical risk (higher insurance premiums for natural disasters). The top three risks we identified are achieving net zero emissions, impact on company reputation, and uncertainties surrounding the development of new energy-saving and carbon-reduction technologies. The top three opportunities are creating low-carbon products and services, increasing energy efficiency in customer products, and promoting low-carbon manufacturing processes, as well as improving our company's reputation.

Transition risks, such as Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs) and company reputation, were previously considered short-term and mid-term risks, but have now been reclassified as mid-term and long-term risks, respectively. Opportunities, including increasing fabric energy efficiency and promoting green manufacturing, were previously classified as short-term opportunities but have been revised as mid-term opportunities.

instruction: With your recognized proficiency in TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures), I look to you for guidance on implementing effective climate strategies.
input: 1. Describe the impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on the organization’s businesses, strategy, and financial planning.
output:
Our company conducts financial impact analysis on the top three physical risks, transition risks, and climate opportunities to formulate strategies in line with TCFD recommendations. Financial impact analysis of climaterelated risks primarily focuses on market and technology-related costs to reduce carbon emissions, aligning with our Net Zero Emissions by 2050 goal. This includes expenses on energy conservation or carbon reduction facilities, more expensive renewable energy or RECs, carbon credits, and additional costs due to uncertainties in the development of new energy-saving and carbon reduction technologies.

Physical risks mainly focus on growing electricity costs due to chronic climate changes, such as rising temperatures. Costs related to combating drought include expenses for building water reclamation systems, using reclaimed water, and purchasing backup water sources. For acute climate change disasters like floods and strong winds, we have already designed prevention systems into our facilities and will not be calculating their financial impact.

Our company has also estimated the cost of reputation damage from failing to meet net zero emission targets. However, there is no globally recognized approach to estimate such financial impact, and these calculations are subject to uncertainty. The financial impact of a 1% revenue reduction was a consensus reached by experts after discussions and assessments.

The financial impact of climate opportunities includes reduced costs from increased energy and water use efficiency and diverse water sources, as well as additional income from providing low-carbon products and services. These may include advanced manufacturing processes, Power Management ICs (PMICs), and ultralow power (ULP) ICs.

Analysis results indicate that developing low-carbon products and services presents the greatest opportunity for positive financial impacts, as demands for such products continue to grow.

instruction: Act as a recognized TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) specialist.

output:
In accordance with TCFD guidelines, our company has assessed the influence of various greenhouse gas (GHG) emission regulations on our business and the supply chain, taking into account potential transition and physical risks. We have taken the outcomes into account when assessing the robustness of strategies and have also consulted the most recent physical science findings, published by the International Energy Agency (IEA) and Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to establish our own climate models. Furthermore, we have incorporated the potential increase in carbon emissions from expanding our operations and new facilities, as well as existing carbon reduction measures, into our evaluations to examine the potential financial consequences of climate risks. Previously, we assessed climate risks based on the worst-case scenario alone. However, the future of climate change is uncertain, and as a result, we have chosen to evaluate climate risks under multiple scenarios this year to help shape and communicate internal strategies, as well as to offer a comprehensive understanding of climate trends over the medium-to-long term.

Climate Scenario Selection
Regarding transition risks, there is now a global agreement that carbon pricing mechanisms are essential for achieving net zero emissions. We consulted the World Energy Outlook 2022 (WEO), an IEA report widely used by companies worldwide, and selected the Net-Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario (NZE) and Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS) to conduct climate risk analysis on future carbon pricing. The resulting carbon pricing serves as the foundation for us to evaluate the effects of carbon pricing schemes on our operations in various countries.

In terms of physical risks, we consulted the Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) published by IPCC in 2021 and the latest Global Climate Model (GCM) to estimate long-term climate changes in the future. We also adopted the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP) to derive GHG emissions under different social and economic contexts. Our impact analysis on physical risks encompasses climate change evaluations across every region of the world and offers detailed impact assessments to our locations and suppliers around the world through downscaling analysis.

Relevant short-, medium-, and long-term time horizons: In our strategic business planning, we consider ‘short-term’ to be less than two years, ‘medium-term’ to be two to five years, and ‘long-term’ to be beyond this. For climate scenario analysis, we can run 30-year scenarios for both Physical and Transition Risk. Some elements of our Physical Risk scenario analysis can also extend to the end of the century.

Processes used to determine material risks and opportunities: We utilize a range of tools and methodologies to assess Transition and Physical Climate Risk for our clients, portfolios, and our own operations. These include scenario analysis, location-based hazard and risk scores, temperature alignment scores, and third-party risk assessment tools (acute physical risk impact assessments). In addition, we engage with our corporate clients to understand their transition and physical risks, as well as their plans to prepare for climate change. In 2022, we continued to enhance our understanding of climate-related risks and significantly strengthened our stress testing and scenario analysis abilities for a range of management scenarios that are more plausible.

Climate-related risk and opportunities identified: We have assessed the impact of Climate Risk on our business using scenario analysis over a 30-year time horizon, which has enabled us to identify and mitigate climate risks which may manifest. Sustainability and climate change have moved from being predominantly risk-based initiatives to becoming a value driver. This gives us an opportunity to deploy our market and industry knowledge to advise our clients on their individual sustainability journeys. Sustainable finance is an opportunity to both defend our existing business from Transition Risk and to fund our clients' transition from a high-carbon present to a low-carbon future. Through supporting clients on their net zero journeys and providing further finance to clients as they adapt to be less carbon intensive and emitting over time, we help mitigate their, and our, Transition Risk. Our aim to achieve Sustainable Finance income of $1 billion by 2025 and to mobilize $300 billion of Sustainable Finance by 2030 are measures of this success. We do not fully disclose impacts on financial planning and performance (including proportions of income, costs, and balance sheet related to climate-related opportunities), detailed Climate Risk exposures for all sectors and geographies, or physical risk metrics. Data limitations, and our plans to mitigate these, are discussed in greater detail in the report.

Significant concentrations of credit exposure to carbon-related assets: We have disclosed our exposures to high-carbon sectors, which includes the expected credit losses on these balances as well as the maturity profiles associated with them. Our exposure to high-carbon sectors makes up 14.4% of our loan balances. We aim to become net zero in our financed emissions by 2050, with interim 2030 targets for our highest emitting sectors. In 2022, we made progress towards this goal and set out to measure, manage, and reduce emissions starting with our most carbon-intensive sectors, in line with our net zero roadmap.

Impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on business strategy:

Our sustainable finance priorities, including new emerging products such as sustainable deposits, carbon trading, and ESG Advisory, and dedicated transition frameworks, represent a strong response to transition risks in the short term, fortifying our resilience towards a 2°C or lower transition scenario.

input:

output:
Processes for identifying and assessing risk:
To support the management and monitoring of Physical and Transition risks, our company continues to conduct case-level reviews for enhanced due diligence on high risks for our corporate clients. The toolkits are used to identify and assess:
- Physical Risk: current-day and longer-term time horizons (representative concentration pathway (RCP) scenarios 2.6, 4.5 and 8.5), for acute weather events (e.g. storms, floods or earthquakes) and chronic sea-level rise.
- Transition Risk: translates Orderly, Disorderly and ‘Hot-House’ world transition scenario variables from relevant sources to financial impact at a client level.

Further information on client-level assessments can be found on a generic page, and the limitations of our methodology can be found on a different generic page.

We define Climate Risk as the potential for financial loss and non-financial detriments arising from climate change and society’s response to it. Within this, we assess and define sub-risk types in the form of a climate risk taxonomy which includes:
- Physical Risk: Risk arising from increasing severity and frequency of climate and weather-related events.
- Transition Risk: Risks arising from the adjustment towards a carbon-neutral economy, which will require significant structural changes to the economy.

Existing and emerging regulatory requirements related to climate change:
Our company has established a process for tracking various Climate Risk-related regulatory developments and obligations set by both financial and non-financial service regulators at our organization and regional/country level. Roles and responsibilities are set out in our Climate Risk Policy. Regulatory requirements or enhancements needed are recorded through workplans across various teams. The workplans are coordinated and monitored through various working groups by having the relevant accountable executives participate in the relevant forums.

Characterising climate-related risks in the context of traditional banking industry risk categories:
Our company has identified seven Principal Risk Types (PRT) that are most materially impacted by potential climate risks and describe transmission channels for Climate Risk manifesting as financial and non-financial risk.

Our company's Direct Operations:
Risk management in our organization encompasses all functions, including evaluating risks related to financial and market performance, operational performance, emergency preparedness and response, environment, health and safety compliance, and regulatory impacts. We prioritize risks based on their impact on our business, employees, communities, and customers. Our Enterprise Risk Management program identifies, assesses, prioritizes, and manages key enterprise risks, with climate-related risks and opportunities being part of this process.
Our Finance, Internal Audit, Legal, and Investor Relations departments identify and assess domestic and international business risks, financial risks, market risks, and environmental compliance risks. These risks are reviewed as part of financial disclosure requirements. In addition, departments such as Environment, Health and Safety, Corporate Sales and Marketing, Legal, Operations, and Investor Relations assess specific physical and transitional risks and opportunities due to climate change. We have evaluated potential physical climate change risks to major facilities, including sea level rise flooding, susceptibility to and preparation for high intensity storms, increased rainfall, drought, and water stress and availability. Both company-level and asset-level physical and transitional risks have been considered, as well as raw material sourcing issues and distribution channel impacts. We use $1 million USD as a benchmark for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company employs a materiality assessment to review and prioritize sustainability topics, including corporate governance, products, environmental protection (including climate change), social responsibility, and economic performance. Our top management is consulted to discuss which aspects are most relevant for our company's future success, and external stakeholders are consulted to understand their perspectives. The results from the materiality assessment guide us toward which areas to focus on in the future. Our Environment, Health & Safety department is responsible for maintaining our ISO 14001 certifications. Our ISO 14001 environmental management systems involve assessing environmental impacts of our manufacturing operations, including those impacted by climate change. Significant impacts for each site covered under an ISO 14001 certification are determined using a ranking system.
We have established corporate-wide goals to manage climate-related risks. Our sustainability goals include a climate change-related target of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions by 50% by 2030 relative to a base year. We also have a long-term goal of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions in line with global climate agreements to further reduce our climate impact and support limiting warming to 1.5°C and transitioning to a net-zero carbon economy.
Upstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on the suppliers of our raw materials. As we rely on global suppliers for raw materials, their locations may be subject to various supply constraints, including those due to climate change. In situations where our company depends on a limited number of suppliers for certain raw materials, components, services, and equipment used in the production of our products, climate change-related risks could affect us. For instance, chronic drought or flooding could increase instability in regions of the world that supply critical raw materials, causing business interruptions. We use $1 million USD as a benchmark for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company assesses upstream risks by calculating our upstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Procurement department manages both physical and transitional risks and opportunities in our supply chain. Our dedicated staff, Supplier Code of Conduct, Purchase Order Terms and Conditions, and Responsible Sourcing Policy help us manage potential supply chain risks, including those associated with climate change. Where feasible, we seek to obtain goods and services from local suppliers in the locations where we conduct business, which helps reduce our risk of business interruptions when climate-related issues may arise and lowers transportation emission impacts.
Downstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on our business downstream. We believe climate change presents a potential opportunity for us because our products are specifically designed to reduce energy consumption and GHG emissions compared to incumbent technologies. However, climate-related events could cause delays in product distribution, resulting in commercial risks associated with delivering our products in a timely manner. We use $1 million USD as a benchmark for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company assesses downstream risks by calculating our downstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Corporate Sales and Marketing department manages our climate-related transitional risks and opportunities, including those related to our product sales, our reputation, market projections, and consumer preferences. We assess market trends and technology advancements to suggest what our business focus should be. For example, we have shifted our strategic focus toward our semiconductor business due to the anticipated increased adoption of energy-efficient technologies that use our products (e.g., renewable energy, electric vehicles).

Answer the following questions:

output: At our company, sustainability and climate action are prioritized both from the top-down and bottom-up. The Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO) spearheads all sustainability initiatives and chairs the Sustainability Steering Board (SSB). This committee oversees sustainability activities and takes necessary actions. In this role, the SSB is accountable for our strategic approach to climate change issues across the value chain, including setting targets, key performance indicators (KPIs), and assessing climate change risks and opportunities. For the current reporting period, climate change was a focal point at every board meeting, meaning it was discussed quarterly, encompassing advancements in our carbon-neutral program, environmental portfolio, and scope 3 within our supply chain. The Sustainability Director reports directly to the CSO and oversees the Department of Sustainability, which comprises dedicated climate change experts who evaluate and manage climate change risks and opportunities daily. Throughout the organization, sustainability is further reinforced by our global network of Country Sustainability Managers and Businesses, whose responsibility is to collaborate with their respective CEOs in executing sustainability efforts at the local level. This structure ensures the effective and accurate implementation of all measures and initiatives.

instruction: Function as a seasoned professional in the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) arena.
input:

1. Describe the climate-related risks and opportunitiesthe organization has identiffed over the short, medium and long term.
output: Our company views the transition to a low carbon economy as an opportunity rather than a substantial risk that would have a material impact on our business. In our fiscal year 2019, we managed to reduce 637 (million metric ton) CO2 at customer sites through our environmental portfolio. We aim to reduce the carbon footprint of our own operations by half by 2020 compared to 2014 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2030. We integrate climate change risk into our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) process, which covers areas such as legal, market, regulatory, and physical risk, and categorizes them into one of the four dimensions – Strategic, Operations, Financial, and Compliance. An example of a risk within the Compliance dimension is the European F-gas regulation (EU) 517 / 2014, which includes the reduction of SF6. Our company is subject to this regulation and currently has 24 sites using SF6. The reduction of SF6 is one element of our efforts to become carbon neutral by 2030. We achieved a reduction of almost 6% last year and 54% since 2014.

input:

1. Describe the organization’s processes for managing climate-related risks.
output:
Our company integrates the management of climate-related risks into our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system. Our ERM approach is based on globally accepted standards, such as the COSO Standard "Enterprise Risk Management – Integrating with Strategy and Performance" (2017) and the ISO Standard 31000 (2018). These frameworks are adapted to our specific business needs.

The ERM process is connected to our financial reporting process and our internal control system. The strategy of our organization, the efficiency and effectiveness of our business operations, the reliability of our financial reporting, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations are considered equally important. ERM is based on a net risk approach and covers risks and opportunities that remain after the execution of existing control measures. Relevant risks and opportunities are prioritized based on their potential impact and likelihood.

Responsibilities are assigned for all relevant risks and opportunities, with the level of responsibility depending on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. The time horizon for risk management is typically three years, but our ERM system also includes a long-term forward-looking feature to monitor emerging risks and opportunities beyond three years up to a century. Assessment is based on the potential impact and velocity of the risks and opportunities.
